lens.analysis_angle: Zillow's size and organizational structure make it structurally unable to serve mid-term shared housing. Zero Zillow mentions in 68 transcripts.
lens.element_thesis: Each element below encodes a structural disability of Zillow into a buildable UI component. These are not features Zillow chose not to build — they are features Zillow's resource allocation processes (Ch 5), growth requirements (Ch 6), and planning methods (Ch 7) will rationally, correctly kill. Every element traces to a validated disappointment, a ranked opportunity, and a Christensen chapter that explains why the incumbent cannot respond.

elements.name: Week-Pattern Search Filter with Day-of-Week Selector, Duration Slider, and Schedule-Flexibility Toggle
elements.problem_it_solves: No housing platform in any category lets users search by schedule. A management consultant who works Tuesday-Thursday in Chicago must manually evaluate 4,200 Zillow results that all assume 7-day occupancy. The search engine is blind to time. This element makes time the primary search dimension — the thing you enter first, before location, before price.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: When a traveling nurse enters 'Monday-Friday, 13 weeks, Nashville' and gets results from hosts who specifically offer that arrangement, the moment of recognition — 'this platform sees me' — is the signature. No platform in real estate, hospitality, or coworking has ever treated schedule as a first-class search dimension. This is the beer sommelier: excellence in a dimension the entire category treats as irrelevant.
elements.description: A search filter component that places schedule above all other search dimensions. Features: (1) A row of 7 day-of-week toggle buttons (M T W T F S S) using Split Lease's signature day badges, where selected days light up in purple. (2) A duration slider from 4 weeks to 52 weeks with labeled tick marks. (3) A 'Schedule Flexibility' toggle with three states: Exact (these days only), Flexible (+/- 1 day), and Approximate (show similar patterns). The flexibility toggle addresses the Schedule Uncertainty Paradox (new-003) — users who don't know their exact schedule yet. The entire filter is positioned ABOVE the location and price filters, signaling that schedule is the most important thing about your housing need.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal strip, full-width, positioned at the top of the search panel above location/price filters
visual_spec.day_badges: 7 circular badges, 40px diameter, 8px gap between each. Inactive: bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6), text-light-gray (#9ca3af). Active: chat-purple (rgb(75, 71, 206)), white text. Hover: bg-off-white with purple-tinted border.
visual_spec.duration_slider: Range input, min 4, max 52, step 1. Track: 4px tall, bg-light-gray. Fill: secondary-purple gradient. Thumb: 20px circle, white with purple-sm shadow.
visual_spec.flexibility_toggle: Three-option segmented control. Inactive segment: bg-light-gray, text-gray. Active segment: secondary-purple background, white text. Border-radius: rounded-pill (20px).
visual_spec.hierarchy_signal: The day selector row is visually dominant (largest elements, highest contrast). Duration is secondary. Flexibility is tertiary. This visual hierarchy communicates: your schedule matters most.
visual_spec.container: Background: white. Border: 1px border-color. Border-radius: rounded-xl (12px). Padding: 24px. Shadow: shadow-purple-sm on hover.

interaction_spec.day_toggle: Tap/click to toggle day on/off. Immediate visual feedback with 0.1s transition. Minimum 2 days required to search.
interaction_spec.duration_slider: Drag or tap to set duration. Real-time label update showing 'X weeks (Month Day - Month Day)' based on today's date.
interaction_spec.flexibility_toggle: Tap to switch between Exact, Flexible, Approximate. Tooltip on each explains the behavior.
interaction_spec.search_trigger: Results update in real-time as user modifies the schedule filter (debounced 300ms). No separate 'Search' button needed for schedule changes.
interaction_spec.empty_state: If no days are selected, show prompt: 'Select your days to find schedule-matched housing'
interaction_spec.keyboard: Tab between day badges, Enter/Space to toggle. Arrow keys navigate duration slider.

elements.name: Ghost Roommate Trust Profile Card with Verification Stack, Compatibility Signals, and Living-Style Indicators
elements.problem_it_solves: When Frederick considers sharing a bedroom with someone she'll never physically overlap with, she has zero information about who that person is. Zillow shows 42 photos of granite countertops but nothing about the human. Hemeden demands to meet guests to 'make sure they're not crazy.' Dimitri demands a driver's license. Every trust mechanism is currently human-mediated because no platform provides native trust infrastructure for ghost roommates.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in real estate, hospitality, or any adjacent category has built trust infrastructure for people who share intimate space with someone they may never physically overlap with. The Ghost Roommate Trust Barrier (new-004) is a trust problem without precedent. This card makes the invisible person visible — showing who you'll share space with, how they've been verified, and what their living patterns look like.
elements.description: A profile card that appears on listing detail pages and within the proposal flow, showing the other party's trust credentials in a layered stack. Layer 1 (instant, System 1): Verified photo, first name, and a one-line identity tag ('Travel nurse from Atlanta, 3 arrangements completed'). Layer 2 (2-second scan): Verification badges — ID verified, background checked, payment pre-authorized — using Split Lease's purple badge system. Layer 3 (on-demand, System 2): Living-style indicators — schedule pattern (the days they typically stay), cleanliness rating from past hosts, communication response time, and a brief lifestyle note ('Early riser, works remotely, quiet evenings'). The card is mutual — both host and guest see each other's version, reinforcing the bilateral trust architecture.

visual_spec.layout: Card, 320px wide, vertical stack. Photo at top (80px circle), name and tag below, badges in a row, living-style details in expandable section.
visual_spec.photo_area: 80px circle avatar with 3px purple border (secondary-purple) indicating verified status. Unverified would show gray border.
visual_spec.name_tag: Name: Inter 18px bold, primary-purple. Tag: DM Sans 14px normal, text-gray. Single line, truncated with ellipsis if needed.
visual_spec.badge_row: Horizontal row of 3-4 badges. Each badge: 28px icon + label. Icon: purple circle with white checkmark. Label: Inter 11px semibold, text-gray. Badges: 'ID Verified', 'Background Checked', 'Payment Secured'.
visual_spec.living_style: Expandable section below badges. Collapsed: 'View living style' link in secondary-purple. Expanded: 4 rows showing schedule pattern (day badges), cleanliness score (purple bar), response time ('< 2 hours avg'), lifestyle note (italic DM Sans).
visual_spec.container: Background: white. Border: 1px border-color. Border-radius: rounded-xl (12px). Padding: 20px. Shadow: shadow-sm, shadow-purple-sm on hover.
visual_spec.mutual_indicator: Small label at top-right: 'They see your profile too' in text-light-gray, 11px. This reinforces bilateral transparency.

interaction_spec.expand_living_style: Tap 'View living style' to expand. Smooth 0.3s slide-down animation. Collapse on second tap.
interaction_spec.photo_tap: Tapping the photo opens a larger version with verification timestamp ('ID verified Feb 2, 2026').
interaction_spec.badge_tooltip: Hovering/tapping a badge shows what it means: 'ID Verified: Government ID matched to profile photo by Split Lease team.'
interaction_spec.mutual_signal: The 'They see your profile too' label subtly pulses once on first view to draw attention to the bilateral nature.

elements.name: Bilateral Proposal Builder with Structured Term Negotiation, Price Translation, and Min-Max Guardrails
elements.problem_it_solves: Every housing platform uses a one-directional power dynamic: landlord sets terms, tenant applies, landlord accepts or rejects. Steven Mariscal translated between monthly and nightly rates during a phone call. Tamycka's agent offered to 'help you negotiate as best as you can.' Every negotiation is human-mediated because no platform provides the tool. This element encodes what agents do on phone calls into a structured digital interface.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: The concept of a bilateral, structured housing negotiation — where both parties have equal standing and clear tools — doesn't exist anywhere. For shared housing, where every arrangement is custom by definition, this negotiation interface IS the product. Two strangers crafting an arrangement that neither could have specified alone, with the platform doing the translation work.
elements.description: A two-panel proposal interface. Left panel: the guest's proposal (selected days, duration, proposed nightly rate, house rules acknowledgment). Right panel: the host's current terms (listed rate, available days, minimum stay, house rules). Between them: a 'meeting zone' that shows where the two proposals overlap and where they differ. Differences are highlighted with a suggested midpoint. Price is shown in both nightly and monthly formats simultaneously (solving Steven's translation problem). The host can accept, counter-propose (modifying specific fields), or decline with a structured reason. Guardrails prevent unreasonable proposals: the host sets a min-max price range, and the guest's proposal must fall within it or include a message explaining why.

visual_spec.layout: Side-by-side panels on desktop (each 280px min), stacked on mobile. 'Meeting zone' as a colored overlay between panels on desktop, or a summary section between stacked cards on mobile.
visual_spec.guest_panel: Background: bg-off-white. Border-left: 3px solid secondary-purple. Header: 'Your Proposal' in Inter 14px semibold, secondary-purple.
visual_spec.host_panel: Background: bg-white. Border-left: 3px solid primary-purple. Header: 'Host Terms' in Inter 14px semibold, primary-purple.
visual_spec.meeting_zone: Background: linear-gradient(to right, rgba(109,49,194,0.05), rgba(49,19,93,0.05)). Overlapping terms shown with green-purple checkmark. Differing terms shown with accent-purple highlight and suggested midpoint.
visual_spec.price_display: Dual format always visible: '$85/night' primary (Inter 20px bold), '$1,190/month for your pattern' secondary (DM Sans 14px, text-gray). Both update in real-time as terms change.
visual_spec.guardrail_indicator: If guest's proposed price is within host's range: subtle green-purple border. If outside: amber border with tooltip 'Outside host's range — include a note explaining your offer.'

interaction_spec.guest_edits: Guest can modify: days, duration, nightly rate (within guardrails), start date. Each field has inline edit with immediate price recalculation.
interaction_spec.host_response: Host sees three buttons: 'Accept Proposal' (primary CTA, secondary-purple), 'Suggest Changes' (outline button), 'Decline' (text link, muted). 'Suggest Changes' opens inline editors on specific fields — host modifies only what they want to change.
interaction_spec.real_time_translation: As guest changes nightly rate, monthly equivalent updates instantly. As guest changes days-per-week, the monthly cost updates. Price is never ambiguous.
interaction_spec.guardrail_flow: If proposal is outside host's range, a message field becomes required. The guest writes a brief note explaining the offer. This preserves negotiation dignity while preventing spam.
interaction_spec.counter_notification: When host counters, guest receives a notification showing exactly which terms changed, with old and new values highlighted.

copy_spec.guardrail_message: Your offer is outside the host's preferred range. Add a note to explain.

before.experience: User clicks 'Apply' and gets redirected to a third-party portal. She enters SSN, employment history, pays a $50 fee. Then: nothing. No status tracker, no negotiation, no back-and-forth. The application is a one-way submission into a void. If she wants different terms, she must find the landlord's phone number and call.
before.emotion: Powerless. A supplicant requesting permission to rent, with no voice in the terms.

after.experience: User sees her proposal side-by-side with the host's terms. She can see where they agree (schedule, duration) and where they differ (rate). The platform suggests a midpoint. She can adjust her offer or submit as-is. The host can accept, counter specific terms, or decline with a reason. Both parties shape the arrangement together.
after.emotion: Empowered. 'We're crafting this arrangement as equals. I have a voice in where I live.'

implements_principles: Bilateral negotiation replaces one-directional application (opp-003 thesis)
Real-time price translation: nightly and monthly always visible (Steven Mariscal's phone call encoded)
Guardrails prevent unreasonable proposals without removing agency (Chantel's min-max insight)
Structured fields prevent negotiation-as-unstructured-messaging anti-pattern
Christensen Ch 5: Process-as-disability — Zillow's one-directional flow cannot become bilateral

elements.name: Three-Tap Date Swap Card with Financial Impact Preview and Host Auto-Notification
elements.problem_it_solves: Nneka (host) said 'that's the frustrating part — I had to go through you guys' about rescheduling dates. Vince (guest) asked 'is there a times when I could just do one night a week, like if after six months my schedule changes.' Every date change currently requires going through Split Lease's team manually. This element makes date changes as easy as rescheduling a calendar meeting — three taps, instant confirmation.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Every platform defines its product as the transaction: finding, booking, signing. What happens after is not their problem. Split Lease flips this. The platform's core product is the living rhythm. When a guest swaps Thursday for Tuesday with three taps, the host is notified instantly, and the price adjusts — that choreographed moment is the signature. Nobody else owns the 80% of housing that happens after the lease.
elements.description: A compact card that appears in the Stays Manager, showing the current week's scheduled nights. Each night is a tappable element. To swap a night: (1) Tap the night you want to remove (it highlights in red-fade). (2) Tap the day you want to add (it highlights in purple-glow). (3) Confirm with a single 'Swap' button. Below the swap, a financial impact line shows the price difference (if any) between the removed and added night. The host receives an instant notification with the swap details and can approve or flag within the same interface.

visual_spec.layout: Card, full-width within the Stays Manager. 7-day row at top, action area below, financial impact at bottom.
visual_spec.day_row: 7 day columns, each showing day abbreviation + date. Scheduled nights: chat-purple background, white text. Available nights: bg-light-gray, text-gray. Unavailable: hatched pattern, muted.
visual_spec.removal_state: Tapped-to-remove night: background fades from purple to a soft red-purple (rgba(200,50,80,0.15)), with strikethrough animation on the day label.
visual_spec.addition_state: Tapped-to-add night: background glows from gray to purple (secondary-purple with 0.15 opacity), with a '+' icon appearing.
visual_spec.confirm_button: 'Swap Thu → Tue' button centered below the row. Secondary-purple background, white text, rounded-pill. Disabled until both remove and add are selected.
visual_spec.financial_line: Below button: 'No price change' or '+$10 (Tuesday is peak rate)' in DM Sans 13px. Green-purple for no change, amber for increase, secondary-purple for decrease.
visual_spec.container: Background: white. Border-radius: 12px. Border: 1px border-color. Padding: 16px. Shadow: shadow-sm.

interaction_spec.tap_to_remove: First tap on a scheduled night marks it for removal. Visual: purple fades to red-tinted. Second tap deselects.
interaction_spec.tap_to_add: Tap on an available (non-scheduled) night marks it for addition. Visual: gray glows to purple-tinted. Only one add allowed per swap.
interaction_spec.confirm: Tap 'Swap' button. Shows a 1-second confirmation animation (checkmark pulse). Host is notified instantly.
interaction_spec.undo: For 10 seconds after confirmation, an 'Undo' link appears. After 10 seconds, the swap is final.
interaction_spec.host_notification: Host sees: 'Maria swapped Thu Mar 19 → Tue Mar 17. No price change.' with Approve/Flag buttons.

elements.name: Cleaning Handoff Checklist with Photo Verification, Turnover Timeline, and Shared-Space Status Dashboard
elements.problem_it_solves: Frederick nearly abandoned shared housing entirely because the cleaning burden seemed 'like I'm moving every single week.' Chantel built a physical inventory book — 'a detailed inventory list' — because no platform manages turnover. The Cleaning Coordination Anxiety (new-002) is severe enough to kill deals for the entire category. This element digitizes Chantel's book and resolves Frederick's anxiety.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in any category manages the turnover between ghost roommates. This is the operational detail that can kill the entire shared housing concept if left unresolved. When the cleaning handoff is visible, structured, and verified — when Frederick can see that the space was cleaned and inventoried before her Monday arrival — the anxiety evaporates. This is the invisible infrastructure that makes shared housing feel choreographed, not chaotic.
elements.description: A checklist card visible to both host and guest in the Stays Manager. Shows: (1) A turnover timeline — when the previous guest departs, when cleaning happens, when the arriving guest can enter. (2) A checklist of cleaning tasks with photo upload slots (kitchen, bathroom, bedroom, common areas). The departing guest uploads departure photos. The cleaner or host uploads cleaning-completed photos. The arriving guest sees both. (3) A shared-space status indicator: 'Ready for your arrival' (green-purple) when all checklist items are verified, or 'In preparation' (amber) when cleaning is in progress. The element creates accountability without creating confrontation.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, full-width in Stays Manager. Timeline at top, checklist in middle, status badge at bottom.
visual_spec.timeline: Horizontal timeline with 3 nodes: 'Maria departs 6pm Thu' -> 'Cleaning 7-9pm Thu' -> 'You arrive Fri 8am'. Nodes: purple circles connected by a line. Past nodes filled, future nodes outlined.
visual_spec.checklist: 4 rows, each with: area name, checkbox, photo thumbnail (40px square, rounded-lg). Unchecked: gray checkbox. Checked: purple checkmark. Photo slot: dashed border when empty, image thumbnail when uploaded.
visual_spec.status_badge: Full-width bar at bottom. Ready: bg secondary-purple with 0.1 opacity, secondary-purple text, checkmark icon. In preparation: amber-tinted bg, amber text, clock icon.
visual_spec.container: Background: white. Border-radius: 12px. Border: 1px border-color. Padding: 20px. Shadow: shadow-sm.

interaction_spec.photo_upload: Tap photo slot to upload from camera or gallery. Max 5MB per photo. Thumbnail appears immediately.
interaction_spec.checklist_complete: Host/cleaner taps each checkbox as areas are cleaned. When all 4 are checked and photos uploaded, status automatically changes to 'Ready for your arrival.'
interaction_spec.guest_view: Guest sees departure photos + cleaning photos side by side. Can tap any photo to view full-size.
interaction_spec.notification: Guest receives push notification when status changes to 'Ready for your arrival.'
interaction_spec.dispute_path: If arriving guest finds an issue, a 'Report Issue' button opens a structured form (area, description, photo) that notifies the host and Split Lease simultaneously.

elements.name: Multi-Arrangement Reputation Card with Dimensional Scores, Longitudinal Timeline, and Compatibility Preview
elements.problem_it_solves: A traveling nurse who has successfully completed four 13-week shared-housing arrangements arrives at her fifth search with nothing. No reputation. No history. Cristina has been doing Airbnb 'for such a long time' and doesn't remember details. Chantel prefers 'single repeat traveler over multiple guests' but has no mechanism for reputation-based retention. This element makes every completed arrangement a permanent asset that follows you.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in real estate or hospitality shows an accumulated housing identity across multiple arrangements. The traveling nurse carries her Nashville, Chicago, and Denver reputation into her Philadelphia search. A host sees '4 arrangements completed, 98% schedule reliability, verified by 3 hosts' and feels safe accepting her without a phone call. Each arrangement makes the next one easier — that accumulation dynamic is both the surprise and the moat.
elements.description: A reputation card displayed on user profiles, showing: (1) A headline stat: '4 arrangements completed across 3 cities.' (2) Three dimensional scores (0-5 scale, shown as purple-fill bars): Schedule Reliability, Space Respect, Communication. These are aggregated from reviews captured at weeks 4, 8, and completion of each arrangement. (3) A longitudinal timeline: small cards for each completed arrangement showing city, duration, dates, and a one-line host quote. (4) A compatibility preview: when viewed by a potential match, the card highlights dimensions most relevant to their listing (e.g., if the host values quiet, the card surfaces the 'quiet evenings' mentions from past reviews).

visual_spec.layout: Card, 360px wide. Headline stat at top, dimensional bars below, timeline as horizontal scroll of mini-cards, compatibility preview as a highlighted badge at bottom.
visual_spec.headline: Inter 16px bold, primary-purple. '4 arrangements completed across 3 cities' with the number in 28px bold.

visual_spec.timeline: Horizontal scroll of mini-cards (120px wide each). Each: city name (Inter 13px bold), dates (DM Sans 11px, text-gray), one-line host quote in italic.
visual_spec.compatibility_badge: Purple-tinted badge at bottom: 'Strong match for your listing' with relevant dimension highlighted. Only appears when viewed by a potential host/guest.
visual_spec.container: Background: white. Border: 1px border-color. Border-radius: 12px. Padding: 20px. Shadow: shadow-sm.

interaction_spec.compatibility_tap: Tapping the compatibility badge shows which review quotes triggered the match signal.

elements.name: Situation-Based Discovery Prompt: 'Tell Us Your Situation' Entry Flow Replacing Buy/Rent/Sell Navigation
elements.problem_it_solves: A traveling nurse visits Zillow and sees Buy, Rent, Sell, Home Loans. She doesn't fit any box. No platform has built a discovery experience that names and serves the mid-term, flexible, shared-housing need. The four-tab navigation tells her: 'People like you, with needs like yours, are not who we built this for.' This element replaces category-based navigation with situation-based navigation.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: When a housing platform's homepage says 'Tell us your situation' instead of 'Buy / Rent / Sell,' it redefines what a housing platform is. It acknowledges that people's lives are more complex than four boxes. The moment a user sees 'I'm working in a new city for a few months' and thinks 'That's me' — that moment of recognition is the signature. Nobody expects a housing platform to understand the complexity of their life.
elements.description: A homepage entry component that replaces traditional Buy/Rent/Sell tabs with situation-based prompts. Three or four clickable cards, each with an illustration, a headline, and a one-line description: (1) 'I need a place for a few months' — for traveling professionals, temporary relocators. (2) 'I have space on certain days' — for hosts with spare rooms on weeknights or weekends. (3) 'I need somewhere 2-4 days a week' — for hybrid workers, split-week commuters. (4) 'I want to share my home part-time' — for hosts exploring shared arrangements. Each card leads to a tailored onboarding flow that captures schedule, duration, and preferences before showing a single listing.

visual_spec.layout: Centered on homepage, max-width 640px. Cards arranged in a 2x2 grid on desktop, single column on mobile.
visual_spec.cards: Each card: 290px wide, bg-white, border-radius 12px, border 1px border-color, padding 20px. Hover: shadow-purple-sm, border-color shifts to accent-purple with 0.3 opacity.
visual_spec.illustration: 48px icon area at top of each card. Purple-tinted abstract illustration (schedule icon, house icon, calendar icon, sharing icon). Using secondary-purple at 0.15 opacity for background circle.
visual_spec.headline: Inter 16px semibold, primary-purple.
visual_spec.description: DM Sans 14px normal, text-gray. One line max.
visual_spec.prompt_header: Above the grid: 'Tell us your situation' in Inter 28px bold, primary-purple. Below: 'We'll match you with the right options' in DM Sans 16px, text-gray.

interaction_spec.card_hover: Subtle lift: shadow-purple-sm, border-color shifts to purple-tinted.
interaction_spec.card_tap: Navigates to a tailored onboarding flow. Each path captures different information: the guest path asks schedule first, the host path asks availability first.
interaction_spec.animation: Cards fade in sequentially (0.1s delay between each) on page load.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, cards stack vertically with full-width.

before.experience: User sees four tabs: Buy, Rent, Sell, Home Loans. She doesn't fit any box. She clicks 'Rent' and gets a search that assumes 12-month leases. There is no 'mid-term stay' option, no 'shared housing' category, no 'I'm here temporarily' path. She leaves and fragments across Airbnb, Furnished Finder, and Craigslist.
before.emotion: Invisible. 'Maybe I'm overthinking this. Maybe my housing need is weird.'

after.experience: User sees 'Tell us your situation' with four cards that describe her life: 'I need somewhere 2-4 days a week — Hybrid work, split-week commute, or part-time in a new city.' She taps the card and enters a tailored flow that asks about her schedule before anything else. The platform understood her before she searched.
after.emotion: Seen. 'This platform understands that my life doesn't fit into standard categories. I belong here.'

implements_principles: Names the unnamed need (disappoint-009: Discovery Assumption)
Situation-based navigation replaces category-based navigation
Empathy before functionality: the platform acknowledges life complexity
Christensen Ch 7: the discovery UX cannot be designed from market research — it must be discovered through operation
Christensen Ch 5: Zillow's 4-tab navigation mirrors its resource allocation (Buy/Rent/Sell/Loans = revenue streams)
